awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology: Genomic and Behavioral Insights into the Role of Mate Choice in the Origins and Maintenance of Biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. While learning new research skills, the fellow will use a marine worm to explore a major source of biodiversity. Different populations of animals sometimes begin to evolve differences in how their offspring develop. These population differences can set the stage for the evolution of new biodiversity. They can even lead to the origins of new species. Whether this happens depends on whether members of the diverging populations can still mate and produce offspring. A common barrier to such matings consists of female mate preferences for males with the same developmental traits. Such preferences can reduce chance matings between divergent populations and allow them to diverge further. Thus, they can be major sources of biodiversity. Yet, how these preferences arise is largely unknown. Using genomics, molecular techniques, and behavioral assays, this research aims to uncover the genomic makeup of such mate preferences. In addition, the fellow will develop K-12 lessons, perform public outreach, and mentor students using research data.

The fellow will use the model marine worm system Streblospio benedicti to investigate the role of female mate choice in the divergence of populations that differ in developmental type. In some populations, S. benedicti females produce many small, obligately feeding larvae. In other populations, they produce many fewer, much larger offspring that can develop to adulthood via maternal provisioning. Intermediate developmental types are nearly never found in nature. Yet, they are readily produced in the lab by breeding adults of opposite types. This suggests selection acts against such intermediates in nature. Preliminary evidence suggests female S. benedicti preferentially mate with adult males who had the same larval form as them. Thus, it is possible that a behavioral, prezygotic mating barrier is contributing to population divergence in developmental type. The fellow will use crosses and whole-genome sequencing of females with different mating preferences to pursue this possibility. This research will identify the genetic basis for mate preferences in this system and its association with developmental type and population divergence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to reveal the role of animal mating preferences in the evolution of distinct developmental types and new species. Most marine invertebrate animals with larval life stages develop via one of two alternative routes. One consists of many small eggs that hatch into many tiny larvae that must feed on plankton for some weeks before metamorphosing into the adult lifeform. The other consists of fewer, smaller eggs that hatch into larger larvae with the ability to complete metamorphosis immediately. These alterntives reflect a tradeoff between numbers of offspring per clutch and the rate at which those offspring develop to the relatively secure adult life stage. Importantly, this tradeoff is thought to underly the evolutionary origins of many distinct marine species. That is, many early lineages likely split along the lines of small, slow-developing larvae and large, fast-developing larvae. Later, these lineages likely became distinct species. Therefore, the opportunity to study a species that exhibits both developmental alternatives provides a window into the likely evolutionary past of much of the oceans' present-day invertebrate biodiversity.

This project used a combination of behavioral asssays, laboratory genetics, and next-generation sequencing to pursue precisely such an opportunity, specifically using the unqiue annelid worm Streblospio benedictii at North Carolina State University. Streblospio benedictii females do a remarkable thing: they mate with males who developed the same way they did (as either small, plankton-feeding larvae, or as large, immediate-metamorphosis larvae). These females achieve this despite the fact that all adult Streblospio benedictii are visually indistinguishable. Importantly, alterntive developmental routes are genetically controlled in Streblospio benedictii. Therefore, these females' preferences for males with the same developmental background may eventually give rise to new species if female preferences are also genetic. That is, by mating only with males of the same developmental type, this female behavior may drive the genetic linkage of adult mating preferences with larval development. As a result, the two developmental types may eventually become distinct, non-interbreeding species.

My efforts generated behavioral data, genotypes, and whole-genome sequencing for nearly 100 individual Streblospio benedictii. These data are currently being analyzed. I expect these data will mark a major leap forward in our understanding of the evolutionary origins of the tremendous biodiversity found among marine invertebrates today. This is because the conditions we see today among Streblospio benedictii likely represent an intermediate evolutionary state that preceded the origins of many present-day species. 

This kind of progress can only come from projects like this one that are designed to study natural populaitons of animals like Streblospio benedictii. Developing and implemeting methods for studying natural populations is difficult, but this NSF-funded project made it possible. These new data on Streblospio benedictii will make major contributions to our understanding of where the tremendous biological diversity that we see today orginally came from.

In addition, this project included training on statistical genetics and bioinformatics, the creation of a new genotyping space at NCSU, and substantial expansion of the research program of the lab in which it was performed.
